facts.text: Ebenezer died intestate on November 22, 1945, during his year of account which ended on March 31, 1946. He left behind him the respondent, Alfred, his son, and eight daughters.
For the assessment year 1946-47, the respondent was assessed under s. 24B of the Income-tax Act, after a notice was issued to him under s. 22(2).
The assessment was completed on March 26, 1951, and a notice of demand was issued under s. 29 of the Act.
The respondent appealed against the order of assessment to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.
During the pendency of the appeal, a penalty of Rs. 250/- was imposed upon him under s. 46(1) of the Act by the Income-tax officer, as he had defaulted in payment of tax on the due date.
After the appeal was disposed of with very minor modifications, a notice of demand was again issued to him to pay the tax on or before December 15, 1951.
On his default, a second penalty of Rs. 10,000/- was imposed upon him on March 8, 1952.
The respondent filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Madras challenging the imposition and levy of penalty imposed upon him.
The High Court held in his favour, and quashed the two orders imposing penalty but granted a certificate of fitness to appeal to this Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the legal representative of a deceased person, who is assessed in respect of the total income of the latter person, as if he were the assessee, can be ordered to pay a penalty under s. 46(1) of the India Income-tax Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: The fiction under s. 24B(2) makes the legal representative an assessee for the purpose of assessment, and this fiction continues for the entire process including levy of tax, default, and penalty under ss. 29, 45, 46. The definition of 'assessee' includes a person by whom income-tax is payable.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 24B, s. 2(2) definition of assessee (pre-1953), s. 23, s. 30, s. 29, s. 45, s. 46(1)

respondent_arguments.text: A legal representative could not be said to be included within the words of s. 46(1). The fiction under s. 24B(2) is limited to assessment and ends after computation of tax. Thereafter, legal representative is not an assessee under s. 29 but 'other person', and ss. 45 and 46 apply only to assessee in default.

court_reasoning.text: The scheme of s. 24B: Sub-s.(1) makes legal representative liable to pay tax out of estate; sub-s.(2) deems legal representative as assessee for assessment purposes where death before notice; this fiction fully works out for entire process of computation and levy of tax.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The word 'assessment' comprehends the entire process of computation and levy of the tax.

court_reasoning.text: Definition of 'assessee' as a person by whom income-tax is payable includes legal representative. Fiction deems respondent assessee for s. 22(2) notice and assessment under s. 23; right to appeal under s. 30 confirms status.
court_reasoning.key_observation: When a thing is deemed to be something else it is to be treated as if it is that thing.

court_reasoning.text: Under s. 29 notice of demand, s. 45 deems assessee in default if not complied; s. 46(1) allows penalty. Respondent went through all stages as assessee. Distinction in s. 29 between assessee and other person does not apply as legal rep is assessee by fiction, not 'other person'.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The words 'other person' cannot apply to a legal representative, if he is an assessee by fiction.

holdings.text: The legal representative is an assessee by fiction under s. 24B(2) for the entire process including liability to penalty under s. 46(1) for default in payment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-Tax v. Teja Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Applied dictum that fiction must be fully worked out without allowing the mind to boggle.

precedents_cited.case_name: East End Dwellings Co., Ltd. v. Finsbury Borough Council
precedents_cited.relevance: Source of dictum on working out fictions fully.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Legal representative liable under s. 24B(1); deemed assessee under s. 24B(2) for assessment; default and penalty under ss. 29, 45, 46(1)

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ petition challenging penalties

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court allowed the appeal, holding that the respondent as legal representative was an assessee by fiction under s. 24B(2) and liable to penalty under s. 46(1) for default in payment of tax.
outcome.relief_granted: Penalties upheld; High Court orders quashing penalties set aside.

key_quotes.text: Whether the legal representative of a deceased person, who is assessed in respect of the total income of the latter person, as if he were the assessee, can be ordered to pay a penalty under s. 46(1) of the India Income-tax Act, is the short question that arises in this appeal.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: When a thing is deemed to be something else it is to be treated as if it is that thing, though, in fact, it is not.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains the effect of statutory fiction.

key_quotes.text: The word assessment bears different meanings, and in one sense, it comprehends the entire process of computation and levy of the tax.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key to extending fiction beyond mere computation.

key_quotes.text: In our opinion, the penalty could be imposed on respondent as an assessee.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Concluding holding in favor of appellant.
